awd_abstract_narration: Dr. Thomas Phillips, in conjunction with ten major users,                       proposes to set up a resource center for immunocytochemistry and                in situ hybridization technologies at the University of                         Missouri.  The center would include, and funds are requested for,               a confocal fluorescence microscope, a computer graphics system                  for three-dimensional reconstruction of confocal microscope                     images, a low-light microscope and camera for fluorescence                      studies, and an associated image processing system for ration                   imaging of indicator dyes to determine cellular pH or ion                       concentrations.  The center will incorporate some already                       existing equipment: a transmission electron microscope,                         microtomes and a cryostat.  This facility would complement                      existing campus-wide cores for monoclonal antibody production and               oligonucleotide synthesis.  Various units within the University                 will provide 50% of the capital costs, long-term salary support                 for staff, substantial existing equipment, and funding for                      laboratory renovation and continuing service contracts.
